unnormalised: E-commerce in India has exploded, hasn't it? From ordering groceries to that fancy new gadget, everything’s just a few clicks away. But have you ever really looked at the numbers behind these online transactions? It's pretty fascinating, and sometimes, a little bit quirky. For example, did you know that the average transaction value on Flipkart during Diwali sales last year was around ₹2500? That's a lot of sarees and diyas!

unnormalised: Think about all the data points generated every single second. Amazon Prime Day saw a whopping 300 million items sold worldwide. And here in India, reports say that nearly 60% of those orders were placed from Tier 2 and Tier 3 cities. That's a huge shift! It means more and more people in smaller towns are getting online and spending their hard-earned ₹. It's also worth noting how COD (Cash on Delivery) is still a popular option, making up nearly 40% of transactions in certain regions. Old habits die hard, eh?

unnormalised: Then there are the deals, the discounts, and the flash sales. Sites like Myntra constantly bombard you with offers like "Flat 50% off!" or "Buy 1 Get 1 Free!". Makes you wonder how they make a profit, right? But consider this: the sheer volume of transactions during these sales probably offsets the reduced margins. I saw a report that stated Myntra's End of Reason Sale generated a GMV (Gross Merchandise Value) of ₹3000 crore in just 5 days. That’s mind-blowing!

unnormalised: Let's talk about payment methods too. While UPI (Unified Payments Interface) is super convenient (and now accounts for ~70% of all online transactions), other options like credit cards and net banking still have their place. You'll often see deals like "10% cashback on HDFC Bank credit cards" to incentivize their use. And of course, digital wallets like Paytm and PhonePe are also in the mix. A recent survey showed that PhonePe processes about 1.5 billion transactions a month.

unnormalised: So, the next time you're scrolling through Amazon or Nykaa, adding stuff to your cart, remember there’s a whole world of numbers ticking away in the background.
